data.description: Road in a residential area
Generally for access to a building, motorway service station, beach, campsite, industrial estate, business park, etc.
Roads for agricultural and forestry use etc.
Public access road, non-residential.
Mainly residential paths designated for pedestrians only.
A road linking small settlements, or the local centres of a large town or city.
A generic multi-use path open to non-motorized vehicles.
A highway linking large towns.
A highway linking large towns.
A bus stop is a place where public buses stop.
Pedestrians can cross a street here - e.g. zebra crossing
A widened area of road that allows vehicles to turn more easily.
For designated cycleways.
A traffic signal for regulating circulation.
Important roads that are not motorways.
Road with very low speed limits and other pedestrian friendly traffic rules
High capacity highways designed to safely carry fast motor traffic.
For flights of steps on footways.
The link roads (sliproads / ramps) leading to and from a motorway.
A single pole with one or more lights to illuminate the street.
For Roads , i.e. mainly / exclusively for pedestrians (often Shopping Areas).
Road with unknown classification.
Used to mark stop signs
An exit from a motorway or other major road.
Used to mark give way signs (also known as yield signs)
A way intended for use by equestrians.
A platform of a bus station.
A road junction where the traffic goes around a painted circle or traversable island and has right of way.
A stone or metal marker on the side of a road denoting the reference and distance travelled.
A fixed road-side or overhead speed camera
Sign number which can be used to define you current position in case of an emergency
Place where drivers can leave the road to rest, but not refuel.
A passing place on a single track road.
A widened area of a highway with a non-traversable island for turning around, often circular and at the end of a road.
An elevator (or lift) is used to travel vertically, providing passenger and freight access between pathways at different floor levels.
A point where a path or road crosses a river or stream which is at times covered by shallow water.
Place where drivers can leave a road to refuel, rest, or take refreshments.
A corridor inside a building
